xxl.core.collections
Class Lists

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.Lists

public class Lists
extends java.lang.Object

This class contains various methods for manipulating lists.

The documentation of the searching methods contained in this class includes a brief description of the implementation. Such descriptions should be regarded as implementation notes, rather than parts of the specification. Implementors should feel free to substitute other algorithms, as long as the specification itself is adhered to.

See Also:
ComparableComparator, Comparator, List

Method Detail

indexOf

public static <S,T extends S> int indexOf(java.util.List<S> list,
                                          T object,
                                          java.util.Comparator<? super S> comparator,
                                          boolean last)
Searches the specified list for the first or last appearance of the specified object using the binary search algorithm. The list must be sorted into ascending order according to the specified comparator before calling this method. If it is not sorted, the results are undefined. If the list contains multiple elements equal to the specified object, the boolean value last decides whether the first or last appearance will be found.

Type Parameters:
S - the type of the elements the given lsit is able to store.
T - the type of the object to be searched for (must be a subtype of S).
Parameters:
list - the list to be searched.
object - the object to be searched for.
comparator - the comparator by which the list is ordered.
last - if false, the first appearance will be found; if true, the last appearance will be found.
Returns:
index of the search object, if it is contained in the list; otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1).
The insertion point is defined as the point at which the object would be inserted into the list: the index of the first element greater than the object, or list.size(), if all elements in the list are less than the specified object. Note that this guarantees that the return value will be ≥ 0 only if the key is found.
Throws:
java.lang.ClassCastException - if the list contains elements that are not mutually comparable using the specified comparator, or the search object is not mutually comparable with the elements of the list using this comparator.

indexOf

public static <S extends java.lang.Comparable<S>,T extends S> int indexOf(java.util.List<S> list,
                                                                          T object,
                                                                          boolean last)
Searches the specified list for the first or last appearance of the specified object using the binary search algorithm. The list must be sorted into ascending order according to the natural ordering of its elements before calling this method. If it is not sorted, the results are undefined. If the list contains multiple elements equal to the specified object, the boolean value last decides whether the first or last appearance will be found.

Type Parameters:
S - the type of the elements the given list is able to store.
T - the type of the object to be searched for (must be a subtype of S).
Parameters:
list - the list to be searched.
object - the object to be searched for.
last - if false, the first appearance will be found; if true, the last appearance will be found.
Returns:
index of the search object, if it is contained in the list; otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1).
The insertion point is defined as the point at which the object would be inserted into the list: the index of the first element greater than the object, or list.size(), if all elements in the list are less than the specified object. Note that this guarantees that the return value will be ≥ 0 only if the key is found.
Throws:
java.lang.ClassCastException - if the list contains elements that are not mutually comparable, or the search object is not mutually comparable with the elements of the list.

firstIndexOf

public static <S,T extends S> int firstIndexOf(java.util.List<S> list,
                                               T object,
                                               java.util.Comparator<? super S> comparator)
Searches the specified list for the first appearance of the specified object using the binary search algorithm. The list must be sorted into ascending order according to the specified comparator before calling this method. If it is not sorted, the results are undefined. If the list contains multiple elements equal to the specified object, the first appearance will be found.

Type Parameters:

T - the type of the object to be searched for (must be a subtype of S).

Note that this guarantees that the return value will be ≥ 0 only if the key is found.
Throws:
java.lang.ClassCastException - if the list contains elements that are not mutually comparable using the specified comparator, or the search object is not mutually comparable with the elements of the list using this comparator.

initializedList

public static <T> java.util.List<T> initializedList(T init,
                                                    int times)
Returns a new list containing the specified object times times.

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the objects the list is able to store.
Parameters:
init - the object that should be inserted times times for initializing the list.
times - the number of times the given object should be inserted.
Returns:
the initialized list containing the specified object times times.

quickSort

public static <E> void quickSort(java.util.List<E> data,
                                 java.util.Comparator<? super E> comparator)
Sort the given list by using the quick sort algorithm for lists. The specified comparator is used for comparing the elements of the list.

Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements stored by the given list.
Parameters:
data - the list to be sorted.
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing the elements of the list.

quickSort

public static <E> void quickSort(java.util.List<E> data,
                                 int l,
                                 int r,
                                 java.util.Comparator<? super E> comparator)
This method performs the quick sort algorithm for lists. The given list is sorted using the specified comparator. The specified indices determine the range of the list that should be sorted by the algorithm. For (ranges of) lists with no more than ten elements the bubble sort algorithm is used, other (ranges of) lists are sorted by a quick sort algorithm using the median of three as pivot element.

Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements stored by the given list.
Parameters:
data - the list to be sorted.
l - the index of the list where the range to be sorted starts.
r - the index of the list where the range to be sorted ends.
comparator - the comparator that is used for comparing the elements of the list.
